description: These adorable little bugs were born weeks apart but are never to be separated. They seem deeply engrossed in their mysterious tasks. I never know where they’re headed, but I love crossing paths with them on my way out the door. Their determination is quite inspiring!
title: Bug #1 & 2

description: Grace in motion, strength in form. Monsieur Danser (his stage name) is a jack of many trades. Before he found me, he shed the fabrics of his second job—a tailcoat, riding pants and a distinguished top hat—at the door. He never explaining their existence, but I may have seen a familiar figure outside a shopping center, a living statue moving only to acknowledge the donations of passers by with a deep and fluid bow.
title: Monsieur Danser

description: Upon discovering metallic paint, I absolutely had to try it, but it took a few weeks before someone showed up who wanted to try them on. She is what I imagine Opera would look like if it was performed without sound. Offstage, she is quiet company—completely at peace within herself, guiding you to do the same.
title: Danser #2

description: Walking fast, faces passing, he’s on his way to pick up his dog from the groomers in his quaint little neighbourhood. Coffee shops and bakeries? Not today! It’s been hours since he’s seen his dog, and he can’t wait another second to see his little face.
title: Making My Way Downtown

description: Holy throwback! This little one showed up, and suddenly, a song was blaring in my mind. Growing up, we had a VHS of Disney’s Sing-Along Songs, featuring By the Beautiful Sea. It’s been ages since I’ve heard it—but the moment this turtle arrived, there it was again, loud and clear with animation included.
title: At the Beautiful Sea

description: Another view of “By the Beautiful Sea”. I very clearly remember Mickey and Minny Mouse playing around with an umbrella on the sand.
title: The Sea from the Seashore

description: There’s a fascinating spot in Dominica called Scott’s Head, where a strip of sand—about the size of a highway lane—separates the Atlantic Ocean from the Caribbean Sea. Swimming on the calmer seaside often meant getting bitten by sea ants, and I always imagined it as the perfect hideaway for fish avoiding sightseers and scuba divers. A perfect home for this little fish.
title: The Sea at Shore

description: Neither you nor I know for sure what lives in the deepest, bluest parts of the Earth’s oceans and seas. You may see a shadow, a vague movement under the surface, something alive moving separately from the waves and currents—but it could just be your imagination.
title: The Sea is Entirely Too Deep

description: Leaving the beach at the end of the day is always at the insistence of grownups, and the pleading of children for just ten more minutes—pleeeeeease? Once everyone’s in the car, the disappointment fades, replaced by the hypnotic winding roads and the layers of soil in the exposed cliffside. If you’d discovered fossils at that age, it was a dizzying challenge trying to spot a real one from the moving car!
title: Beyond Shore

description: Leaving the beach at the end of the day is always at the insistence of grownups, and the pleading of children for just ten more minutes—pleeeeeease? Once everyone’s in the car, the disappointment fades, replaced by the hypnotic winding roads and the layers of soil in the exposed cliffside. If you’d discovered fossils at that age, it was a dizzying challenge trying to spot a real one from the moving car!
title: Beyond Shore #2

description: How did you get here Bougainvillea? I did not summon you at all, and yet here you are, embedded in my bones, appearing as you wish. Much like your thorns after gardening day.
title: Outside Being Gorgeous

description: Red ants were everywhere when I was growing up. They could find me at any hour, announcing themselves with a sharp, stinging bite. Thinking about it now, I haven't seen them in a while... I wonder what they're up to.
title: Spots You Outside Being Gorgeous, Looking Like a Food Source aka The Ant

description: Discovering that canvases come in different shapes was one of the best things to ever happen to me, but triangles…stories do not appear as easily in triangles. Triangles are the mathematics of shapes—I don’t get it, but it adds up!
title: Triangles Resist Context #1-4
Kaleidoscope
description: Déjà vu. Never seeing a kaleidoscope for sale but often being handed one to stay busy during visits while the adults talked. It worked.

title: Breathing Exercises
description: Get comfortable. Breathe in for 4 seconds, out for 8. In again for 4. Breathing exercises are often recommended for reducing anxiety and helping with sleep. 484 is the only one I remembered long term, although I did have to rearrange it to something more familiar.

title: Triangles Resist Context: Pastel Edition
description: What is this? Nothing. And everything. Discovering this texture and sheen was so fun. This is my favourite triangle. Don’t tell the others.

title: Oh, Hey Pac-Man
description: Did you know Pac-Man was designed after a pizza with a missing slice? Did you know there was a TV show about Pac-Man where he has had parents named Zac and Sunny? There are rabbit holes beyond your imagination.

title: Silver Bullet
description: Word to the wise: check in with the moon before you reach the heart of the woods. It’s bad luck realizing it’s a full moon after you’ve wandered into werewolf territory.

title: I’m Uncomfortable: It’s Too Structured
description: And yet, it’s still not structured enough. It feels like a convention where they’ve crammed as many booths as possible into a room. They give you a map, an overhead view, but you're standing on the floor—how are you supposed to know which aisle is number 7? You entered at aisle 10, but the map just says 'You are here.'

title: I Dunno Y’all, I think it’s a Virus
description: One of those rare ones that survives in a volcano, or a boiling river.
image: /paintings/2023/I Dunno Y’all, I think it’s a Virus.png

title: Triangles Resist Context: Using Acrylics Changed Nothing
description: This triangle is Bajan, I am completely unable to explain.

title: The Miners
description: Two stories unfold in this paired set of paintings. On one hand, we have a family-friendly comedy, Home Alone-style; on the other, a Stephen King-esque dimensional escape, where the pink and peach tones carry unsettling implications.

title: J’ouvert
description: J’ouvert, J’ouvert, what can I say about J’ouvert. Sunup to sun down, find your people and leh we go. I mean you go. I’ll see you at lunch—we serving callaloo right?
Water sign, destined for skateboards.
Earth sign, destined for skateboards.

title: The Lake District
description: Guess what country has the most lakes in the world? It’s Canada! As many as 2 million apparently. Lake Superior is clearly the most terrifying. You can disagree, but you would be wrong.

title: Water is Not Everywhere the Same
description: Sometimes lakes are pink, and that’s visually cool. Visually.

title: Things Live in It
description: Creatures of the water, shapeshifting through the ripples. Small and elusive, they rarely have visitors but may occasionally come up to say hi.

title: No Thoughts, Seeing Spots
description: A product of stress relief, this painting emerged without thought. Seeing spots takes me back to the finding of a meditative state, where drawing transformed into a calming surprise—a night sky of quiet serenity.

title: I Don’t Know, it Could Be a Pond (Deceptively Shallow)
description: A deceptively shallow pond, its surface smooth and inviting, but you won’t know its depth until you’re already in it. Don’t trust it, Mary.
image: /paintings/2023/I Don’t Know, it Could Be a Pond .png

title: Many Sky
description: The sky is fickle, it changes often, the least controllable element.

title: Rent is High for What
description: This reminds me of a phone screensaver I once had. It was called Amsterdam, featuring colourful houses and across the street, a tiny woman in a belly shirt, mini skirt, and high-heeled boots. It took me forever to notice her, because a car would drive by and she would disappear for some time before coming back. I can't find that screensaver any more.

title: Panels #1
description: Kind of just vibes.

title: Panels #2
description: Day and night vibes. Specifically the end of August/first week of September. You know the part where you’re still in denial about the end of summer? Yeah. It’s also under the sea prom decor.

title: Everyone is Tired
description: Two figures, both barely holding themselves up. One has extra baggage but still tries to help the other, like two exhausted friends each in the middle of their own mid-week crisis saying, 'Yes, I can take a call right now. Who’re we mad at today?'

title: Titan
description: This is one of my favourites to ask people, 'What do you see?' They never give the same answer, but all I can see is a heart restored Te Fiti being her best self.

title: Dolphins
description: I went whale watching once. Saw no whales, and the dolphins arrived in the last forty minutes of a two-hour boat ride. It cost $80 USD. Highly recommend.

title: Farming Elements
description: Orange isn’t the color I’d associate with a farmer, yet here he is. Tending to the land, creating optimal environments for their crops, and respecting the balance that the elements demand.

title: Titan #3
description: Remember the Titans? Ancient, powerful rulers of earth before the gods took over. Though they’ve stepped back, they never truly left—they exist wherever nature thrives, but they’re still around, silently judging, keeping score of how humans treat the earth.

title: Titan #4
description: Another Titan watches from just above the ground, spared from Tartarus but still apart from the others. She’s the oldest tree you’ve ever met, the tallest hill in your hometown—the one you no longer notice as you pass by.

title: Weeee
description: It’s a bike ride through the countryside, and the song 99 Red Balloons.

title: Eat Em At Night
description: Did you also grow up being told never to eat pineapples at night? Adult me could not avoid testing that rule, and guess what?

title: 3 in 1: Which Side is Up
description: This one was actually a bit intentional, yet it still managed to surprise me. A tree can be a mermaid, but it can also be two trees in different seasons—depending on how you look at it.

title: I Decline Consciousness
description: Trapped in the calming greens of the bedsheet pulling you back into sleep, while the world outside remains relentlessly urgent, demanding your presence. Sometimes sleep wins, other times it’s chosen as an escape from the chaos.

title: The People’s Choice
description: One of the first of many from 2023, and possibly the main reason I kept making them. This painting feels what I feel, and I feel what it feels. The vibe changes depending on the day, but it holds a special place every day, so it has no consistent story—just a persisting pressureless connection.
